title: Identification of polarized macrophage subsets in zebrafish
abstract: While the mammalian macrophage phenotypes have been intensively studied in vitro, the dynamic of their phenotypic polarization has never been investigated in live vertebrates. We used the zebrafish as a live model to identify and trail macrophage subtypes. We generated a transgenic line whose macrophages expressing <italic>tumour necrosis factor alpha</italic> (<italic>tnfa</italic>), a key feature of classically activated (M1) macrophages, express fluorescent proteins <italic>Tg(mpeg1:mCherryF/tnfa:eGFP-F)</italic>. Using 4D-confocal microscopy, we showed that both aseptic wounding and <italic>Escherichia coli</italic> inoculation triggered macrophage recruitment, some of which started to express <italic>tnfa</italic>. RT-qPCR on Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorting (FACS)-sorted tnfa<sup>+</sup> and tnfa<sup>−</sup> macrophages showed that they, respectively, expressed M1 and alternatively activated (M2) mammalian markers. Fate tracing of <italic>tnfa</italic><sup>undefined</sup> macrophages during the time-course of inflammation demonstrated that pro-inflammatory macrophages converted into M2-like phenotype during the resolution step. Our results reveal the diversity and plasticity of zebrafish macrophage subsets and underline the similarities with mammalian macrophages proposing a new system to study macrophage functional dynamic.
